name: ax9v
params: setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2
body: |- wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wi(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s2), cv(s1))))

stmt.origin: a1ii(wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wi(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s2), cv(s1)))), diffss(s0, s1))

body.origin:
|- wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wi(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s2), cv(s1))))
-| wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wi(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s2), cv(s1))))
-| diffss(s0, s1)

cumulated.origin:
|- wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wi(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s2), cv(s1))))
-| wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wi(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s2), cv(s1))))
-| diffss(s0, s1)

body.origin: |- wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wi(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s2), cv(s1))))

cumulated.origin:
|- wi(wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wi(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s2), cv(s1))))
-| diffss(s0, s1)

comment: Weakened version of ~ ax-9 , with a disjoint variable condition on ` x , y ` . This should be the only proof referencing ~ ax-9 , and it should be referenced only by its two weakened versions ~ ax9v1 and ~ ax9v2 , from which ~ ax-9 is then rederived as ~ ax9 , which shows that either ~ ax9v or the conjunction of ~ ax9v1 and ~ ax9v2 is sufficient. (Contributed by BJ, 7-Dec-2020.) Use ~ ax9 instead. (New usage is discouraged.)
